anchor.php

Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 <table class="manual" id="basic">
00002   <caption>anchor</caption>
00003   <tr>
00004     <th>Statement</th>
00005     <th>Description</th>
00006   </tr>
00007   <tr>
00008     <td colspan="2">
00009       <p>Besides the main ruleset, pfctl(8) can load rulesets into anchor attachment points.  
00010          An anchor is a container that can hold rules, address tables, and other anchors.</p>
00011 
00012       <p>An anchor has a name which specifies the path where pfctl(8) can be used
00013          to access the anchor to perform operations on it, such as attaching child
00014          anchors to it or loading rules into it.  Anchors may be nested, with 
00015          components separated by `/' characters, similar to how file system hierarchies 
00016          are laid out. The main ruleset is actually the default anchor, so
00017          filter and translation rules, for example, may also be contained in any
00018          anchor.</p>
00019       
00020       <p>An anchor can reference another anchor attachment point using the following kinds of rules:</p>
00021 
00022       <table>
00023         <tr>
00024           <td class="key">anchor <strong>name</strong></td>
00025           <td>Evaluates the filter rules in the specified anchor.</td>
00026         </tr>
00027         <tr>
00028           <td class="key">nat-anchor <strong>name</strong></td>
00029           <td>Evaluates the nat rules in the specified anchor.</td>
00030         </tr>
00031         <tr>
00032           <td class="key">rdr-anchor <strong>name</strong></td>
00033           <td>Evaluates the rdr rules in the specified anchor.</td>
00034         </tr>
00035         <tr>
00036           <td class="key">binat-anchor <strong>name</strong></td>
00037           <td>Evaluates the binat-anchor rules in the specified anchor.</td>
00038         </tr>
00039         <tr>
00040           <td class="key">load anchor <strong>name</strong> from <strong>file</strong></td>
00041           <td>Loads the rules from the specified file into the anchor name. In pfw, this counfiguration
00042               can be found in the <a href="table.php">table</a> menu.
00043           </td>
00044         </tr>
00045       </table>
00046 
00047 
00048       <p>When evaluation of the main ruleset reaches an anchor rule, pf(4) will
00049          proceed to evaluate all rules specified in that anchor.</p>
00050 
00051       <p>Matching filter and translation rules in anchors with the quick option
00052          are final and abort the evaluation of the rules in other anchors and the
00053          main ruleset.</p>
00054 
00055       <p>anchor rules are evaluated relative to the anchor in which they are contained. 
00056          For example, all anchor rules specified in the main ruleset will
00057          reference anchor attachment points underneath the main ruleset, and
00058          anchor rules specified in a file loaded from a load anchor rule will be
00059          attached under that anchor point.</p>
00060       
00061       <p>Rules may be contained in anchor attachment points which do not contain
00062          any rules when the main ruleset is loaded, and later such anchors can be
00063          manipulated through pfctl(8) without reloading the main ruleset or other
00064          anchors.  For example,</p>
00065 
00066 <pre>
00067 ext_if = "kue0"
00068 block on $ext_if all
00069 anchor spam
00070 pass out on $ext_if all keep state
00071 pass in on $ext_if proto tcp from any to $ext_if port smtp keep state
00072 </pre>
00073 
00074       <p>blocks all packets on the external interface by default, then evaluates
00075          all rules in the anchor named "spam", and finally passes all outgoing
00076          connections and incoming connections to port 25.</p>
00077 
00078         <code># echo "block in quick from 1.2.3.4 to any" | pfctl -a spam -f -</code>
00079 
00080       <p>This loads a single rule into the anchor, which blocks all packets from a
00081          specific address.</p>
00082 
00083       <p>The anchor can also be populated by adding a load anchor rule after the
00084          anchor rule:</p>
00085 
00086 <pre>
00087 anchor spam
00088 load anchor spam from "/etc/pf-spam.conf"
00089 </pre>
00090 
00091       <p>When pfctl(8) loads pf.conf, it will also load all the rules from the
00092          file /etc/pf-spam.conf into the anchor.</p>
00093 
00094       <p>Optionally, anchor rules can specify the parameter's direction, interface, 
00095          address family, protocol and source/destination address/port using
00096          the same syntax as filter rules.  When parameters are used, the anchor
00097          rule is only evaluated for matching packets. This allows conditional
00098          evaluation of anchors, like:</p>
00099 
00100 <pre>
00101 block on $ext_if all
00102 anchor spam proto tcp from any to any port smtp
00103 pass out on $ext_if all keep state
00104 pass in on $ext_if proto tcp from any to $ext_if port smtp keep state
00105 </pre>
00106 
00107       <p>The rules inside anchor spam are only evaluated for tcp packets with 
00108          destination port 25.  Hence,</p>
00109 
00110         <code># echo "block in quick from 1.2.3.4 to any" | pfctl -a spam -f -</code>
00111 
00112       <p>will only block connections from 1.2.3.4 to port 25.</p>
00113 
00114       <p>Anchors may end with the asterisk (`*') character, which signifies that
00115          all anchors attached at that point should be evaluated in the alphabetical 
00116          ordering of their anchor name.  For example,</p>
00117 
00118         <code>anchor "spam/*"</code>
00119 
00120       <p>will evaluate each rule in each anchor attached to the spam anchor.  Note
00121          that it will only evaluate anchors that are directly attached to the spam
00122          anchor, and will not descend to evaluate anchors recursively.</p>
00123 
00124       <p>Since anchors are evaluated relative to the anchor in which they are contained, 
00125          there is a mechanism for accessing the parent and ancestor anchors of a given 
00126          anchor.  Similar to file system path name resolution, if the sequence ``..'' 
00127          appears as an anchor path component, the parent anchor of the current anchor 
00128          in the path evaluation at that point will become the new current anchor. As an 
00129          example, consider the following:</p>
00130 
00131 <pre>
00132 # echo ' anchor "spam/allowed" ' | pfctl -f -
00133 # echo -e ' anchor "../banned" \n pass' | pfctl -a spam/allowed -f -
00134 </pre>
00135 
00136       <p>Evaluation of the main ruleset will lead into the spam/allowed anchor,
00137          which will evaluate the rules in the spam/banned anchor, if any, before
00138          finally evaluating the pass rule.</p>
00139 
00140       <p>Since the parser specification for anchor names is a string, any reference 
00141          to an anchor name containing solidus (`/') characters will require double 
00142          quote (`"') characters around the anchor name.</p>
00143     </td>
00144   </tr>
00145 </table>
00146
